docs.abstract: After a year of debate and criticism, an effort to add to a policy on banned speech led to a narrower restriction that applies only when religious groups are targeted.
docs.snippet: After a year of debate and criticism, an effort to add to a policy on banned speech led to a narrower restriction that applies only when religious groups are targeted.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last August, Twitter’s top executives gathered at the company’s headquarters to discuss how to make the site safer for its users. Two attendees proposed banning all speech that could be considered “dehumanizing.” For an example of what they meant, they showed a sample post that featured the words President Trump used to  compare certain nations to excrement.

headline.main: Twitter Backs Off Broad Limits on ‘Dehumanizing’ Speech
headline.print_headline: What Speech Goes Too Far On Twitter? It’s Limited

docs.abstract: Germany’s top antitrust official is urging other countries to take on Facebook and its peers by attacking what the companies value most: data.
docs.snippet: Germany’s top antitrust official is urging other countries to take on Facebook and its peers by attacking what the companies value most: data.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Germany’s top antitrust enforcer, Andreas Mundt, recently asked a room full of lawyers, academics and regulators to imagine a wall filled with their personal information collected by Facebook and Google. He told them to picture it stocked with their data broken up into categories like finances, location, relationships and hobbies.

headline.main: Big Tech ‘Knows You Better Than Your Wife.’ He Plans to Rein It In.
headline.print_headline: Reining In Big Tech May Rest on Your Data

docs.abstract: The case seemed cold when a Miami Herald investigative journalist started looking into it. Then she persuaded accusers to tell their stories.
docs.snippet: The case seemed cold when a Miami Herald investigative journalist started looking into it. Then she persuaded accusers to tell their stories.
docs.lead_paragraph: Julie K. Brown, an investigative journalist for The Miami Herald, expected to spend the week on the same emotionally brutal endeavor she has pursued for more than two years: interviewing women who say that, as girls, they were part of a sex ring run by the wealthy financier Jeffrey Epstein.

headline.main: The Jeffrey Epstein Case Was Cold, Until a Miami Herald Reporter Got Accusers to Talk
headline.print_headline: Epstein Case Was Cold, Until Reporter Got Accusers to Talk

docs.abstract: Why complicate things with unproven bleeding-edge tech? Jim Kerstetter, deputy tech editor, also shops local and stays away from Uber and Postmates.
docs.snippet: Why complicate things with unproven bleeding-edge tech? Jim Kerstetter, deputy tech editor, also shops local and stays away from Uber and Postmates.
docs.lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Jim Kerstetter, deputy technology editor in San Francisco, discussed the tech he’s using.

headline.main: How a Longtime Tech Editor Keeps His Tech Use Simple
headline.print_headline: A Bleeding-Edge Tech Product? Not for Me, Thanks

docs.abstract: Government lawyers argued in a court filing this week that proof of wrongdoing by the Chinese tech giant was not required to justify barring federal agencies from using its gear.
docs.snippet: Government lawyers argued in a court filing this week that proof of wrongdoing by the Chinese tech giant was not required to justify barring federal agencies from using its gear.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Trump administration says the mere potential for Beijing to influence the Chinese technology giant Huawei is enough to justify a law passed last year restricting federal agencies’ business with the company.

headline.main: ‘Prospective Threat’ of Chinese Spying Justifies Huawei Ban, U.S. Says
headline.print_headline: Spying Threat Alone Justifies Huawei Ban, U.S. Says

docs.abstract: Turkey remains stuck in perilous proximity to economic crisis, as households and businesses defer spending and investment in the face of weak growth.
docs.snippet: Turkey remains stuck in perilous proximity to economic crisis, as households and businesses defer spending and investment in the face of weak growth.
docs.lead_paragraph: ARHAVI, Turkey — The terraced rows of tea plants climbing the hills above the Black Sea used to glint like money. Lately, they look like another casualty of Turkey’s long, grinding economic crisis.

headline.main: Turkey’s Long, Painful Economic Crisis Grinds On
headline.print_headline: More Dilemmas Than Solutions for Turkey’s Financial Crisis

docs.abstract: The private space-tourism business plans to merge with a publicly traded shell company, giving it a stock listing and, potentially a crucial new source of cash.
docs.snippet: The private space-tourism business plans to merge with a publicly traded shell company, giving it a stock listing and, potentially a crucial new source of cash.
docs.lead_paragraph: Richard Branson continues to be in a tight race to be the first to operate a large-scale business bringing tourists into space. On Tuesday, he moved closer to winning a different contest: being the first to achieve that goal with a publicly traded company.

headline.main: Richard Branson’s Virgin Galactic to Go Public

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

docs.abstract: Chip makers’ deals underscore how difficult it is to clamp down on companies that the administration considers a national security threat.
docs.snippet: Chip makers’ deals underscore how difficult it is to clamp down on companies that the administration considers a national security threat.
docs.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — United States chip makers are still selling millions of dollars of products to Huawei despite a Trump administration ban on the sale of American technology to the Chinese telecommunications giant, according to four people with knowledge of the sales.

headline.main: U.S. Tech Companies Sidestep a Trump Ban, to Keep Selling to Huawei
headline.print_headline: U.S. Companies Sell Tech to Huawei Despite Ban

byline.original: By Paul Mozur and Cecilia Kang

docs.abstract: Having a civil case moving forward at the same time isn’t likely to help the Justice Department’s criminal prosecution of Ramesh Balwani, the former chief operating officer of Theranos.
docs.snippet: Having a civil case moving forward at the same time isn’t likely to help the Justice Department’s criminal prosecution of Ramesh Balwani, the former chief operating officer of Theranos.
docs.lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline.main: A Path to Discovery in the Theranos Case

docs.abstract: A resumption of negotiations between Washington and Beijing lifted markets. Still, many doubt the two sides can reach a deal anytime soon.
docs.snippet: A resumption of negotiations between Washington and Beijing lifted markets. Still, many doubt the two sides can reach a deal anytime soon.
docs.lead_paragraph: Shares in technology companies led Wall Street stocks higher on Monday, with global investors buoyed by a thaw in the trade dispute between the United States and China even as prospects for a long-term deal remained uncertain.

headline.main: S&P and Dow Follow Global Markets Higher, as Investors Take Heart in Trade Thaw
headline.print_headline: Investors Take Heart in Trade Thaw

byline.original: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matt Phillips
